This is an important question to consider when evaluating energy sources. The scientific evidence shows that coal energy is significantly more dangerous than nuclear power in terms of health impacts and deaths per unit of electricity generated.

Here are some key facts and figures:

- A major study published in Lancet Planetary Health in 2021 estimated that air pollution from fossil fuels caused 8.7 million premature deaths globally in 2018, with coal the biggest contributor. (Source: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanplh/article/PIIS2542-5196(21)00013-1/fulltext)

- The World Health Organization estimates that air pollution causes 4.2 million deaths annually. Coal combustion is a major source of this pollution. (Source: https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/ambient-(outdoor)-air-quality-and-health)

- In contrast, the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in 1986 caused an estimated 4,000 to 16,000 cancer deaths over the subsequent decades. (Source: https://www.unscear.org/unscear/en/chernobyl.html) 

- The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident in 2011 caused no direct radiation deaths and is expected to cause an estimated 130 to 640 long-term deaths from cancer. (Source: https://www.unscear.org/unscear/en/fukushima.html)

- A 2013 study in Environmental Science & Technology estimated that nuclear power prevents an average of 1,800 premature deaths per year in the U.S. by displacing coal plants. (Source: https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/es3051197)

- The European Commission Research Directorate concluded in 2020 that nuclear power has the lowest mortality rate of any major energy source. (Source: https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/6ba27108-451b-11ea-ba6e-01aa75ed71a1/language-en)

So in summary, while nuclear accidents can cause deaths and long-term health impacts, the routine air pollution from coal energy causes orders of magnitude more deaths and illness each year. The scientific consensus is that nuclear power is much safer than coal.

That said, there are still debates around the long-term safety of nuclear waste disposal, risks of nuclear terrorism, and potential for future accidents. And the health and environmental impacts of uranium mining for nuclear fuel should also be considered. 

Ultimately, most experts believe that the benefits of replacing coal with nuclear power outweigh the risks. But it's a complex issue and there are valid arguments on both sides. Replacing coal with cleaner energy sources like nuclear, wind, and solar could prevent many premature deaths and improve quality of life for millions of people.
